chapter.title: Access Control Lists for Cluster Resources

abstract.para: Administrating clusters with the various tools like the crm shell, &hawk;, or the &hbgui; can only be used by &rootuser; or any user who are part of the hacluster group. In some cases this may be not enough.
With access control lists (ACLs) you can define rules to allow or deny access to a resource. Typically, rules are combined to create specific roles and users may be assigned a role to make access .

sect1.title: Requirements and Prerequisites
sect1.para: Before you start using ACLs on your cluster, make sure the following conditions are fullfilled:

listitem.para: The same users must be available on all nodes in your cluster. Use NIS to ensure this.
All users must belong to the hacluster group.
User &rootuser; and users belonging to the hacluster group has always full access.
Non-privileged users want to run the crm shell, they have to change the PATH variable and extend it with /usr/sbin.
In order to use (advanced) ACLs you need minimum knowledge about XPath. XPath is a language for retrieving nodes in a XML document. Refer to or look into the specification at .

sect1.title: Knowing the Basics of ACLs
sect1.para: An ACL role is a set of rules which describe access rights to CIB. Rules consists of these parts:

listitem.para: Access rights to read, write, or deny,
An XPath expression where to apply this rule.

sect1.para: Using ACLs is usually specifying a role and assigning a role to a user. However, it is also possible to give a certain user specific access rules without defining any roles.
In order to manage ACLs you need to know the structure of the underlying XML. The structure can be retrieved by using the following command:
The output is a XML structure of your cluster configuration (see ).

example.title: Excerpt of a Cluster Configuration in XML
example.screen: <cib admin_epoch="0" cib-last-written="Wed Nov 2 16:42:51 2011" crm_feature_set="3.0.5" dc-uuid="stuttgart" epoch="13" have-quorum="1" num_updates="42" update-client="cibadmin" update-origin="nuernberg" update-user="root"validate-with="pacemaker-1.2"> <configuration> <crm_config> <cluster_property_set id="cib-bootstrap-options"> <nvpair id="cib-bootstrap-options-stonith-enabled" name="stonith-enabled" value="true"/> </cluster_property_set> </crm_config> <nodes> <node id="stuttgart" type="normal" uname="stuttgart"/> <node id="nuernberg" type="normal" uname="nuernberg"/> </nodes> <resources> ... </resources> <constraints/> <rsc_defaults> ... </rsc_defaults> <op_defaults> ... </op_defaults> <configuration> </cib>

sect1.para: With the XPath language you can locate nodes in this XML document. For example, to retrieve the root node (cib) use the XPath expression /cib. To locate the global cluster configurations, use the XPath /cib/configuration/crm_config.

sect1.title: Configuring ACLs with the &hbgui;
sect1.para: Use the &hbgui; to define your roles and users. The following procedure adds a monitor role which has only read access to the CIB. Proceed as follows:

step.para: Start the &hbgui; and log in as described in .
Click the ACLs entry in the Configuration tree.
Click Add. A dialog box appears to choose between ACL User and ACL Role.
Define your ACL role(s):
Choose ACL Role. A window opens to add your configuration options.
Add a unique identifier in the ID textfield, for example monitor.
Click Add and choose the rights (Read, Write, or Deny). In our example, select Read and proceed with Ok.
Insert the XPath expression /cib into the Xpath textfield. Proceed with Ok.
If you have other conditions, repeat the steps ( and ). In our example, this is not the case so your role is finished and you can close the window with Ok.
Assign your role to a user:
Click the Add button. A dialog box appears to choose between ACL User and ACL Role.
Choose ACL User. A window opens to add your configuration options.
Enter the username in the ID textfield.
Click Add and choose Role Ref.
Use the role name specified in .

sect1.title: Configuring ACLs with the crm Shell
sect1.para: The following procedure adds an operator role as shown in and assign it to a user. Proceed as follows:

step.para: Define your ACL role(s):
Log in as &rootuser;.
Start the interactive mode of the crm shell:
Use the role command to define your new roles. This command has the following syntax: following syntax:
To define an operator role, use the following command:
step.screen: role operator \ write xpath:"//crm_config//nvpair[@name='maintenance-mode']" write xpath:"//nodes/node//nvpair[@name='standby']" \ write xpath:"//resources//nvpair[@name='is-managed']" \ write xpath:"//constraints/rsc_location" \ read xpath:"/cib"

step.para: Add additional roles as needed.
Assign your roles to users.
step.screen: crm(live)configure# user &exampleuser; role:monitor crm(live)configure# user &exampleuserII; role:operator
